Riemann Surfaces

  • B1.11

    #Riemann Surfaces
    2001

    Recall that an automorphism of a Riemann surface is a bijective analytic map onto itself, and that the inverse map is then guaranteed to be analytic.

    Let Δ\DeltaΔ denote the disc⁡{z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\operatorname{disc}\{z \in \mathbb{C}|| z \mid<1\}disc{z∈C∣∣z∣<1}, and let Δ∗=Δ−{0}\Delta^{*}=\Delta-\{0\}Δ∗=Δ−{0}.

    (a) Prove that an automorphism ϕ:Δ→Δ\phi: \Delta \rightarrow \Deltaϕ:Δ→Δ with ϕ(0)=0\phi(0)=0ϕ(0)=0 is a Euclidian rotation.

    [Hint: Apply the maximum modulus principle to the functions ϕ(z)/z\phi(z) / zϕ(z)/z and ϕ−1(z)/z\phi^{-1}(z) / zϕ−1(z)/z.]

    (b) Prove that a holomorphic map ϕ:Δ∗→Δ\phi: \Delta^{*} \rightarrow \Deltaϕ:Δ∗→Δ extends to the entire disc, and use this to conclude that any automorphism of Δ∗\Delta^{*}Δ∗ is a Euclidean rotation.

    [You may use the result stated in part (a).]

    (c) Define an analytic map between Riemann surfaces. Show that a continuous map between Riemann surfaces, known to be analytic everywhere except perhaps at a single point PPP, is, in fact, analytic everywhere.

    Let f:X→Yf: X \rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a nonconstant holomorphic map between compact connected Riemann surfaces. Define the valency of fff at a point, and the degree of fff.

    Define the genus of a compact connected Riemann surface XXX (assuming the existence of a triangulation).

    State the Riemann-Hurwitz theorem. Show that a holomorphic non-constant selfmap of a compact Riemann surface of genus g>1g>1g>1 is bijective, with holomorphic inverse. Verify that the Riemann surface in C2\mathbb{C}^{2}C2 described in the equation w4=z4−1w^{4}=z^{4}-1w4=z4−1 is non-singular, and describe its topological type.

    [Note: The description can be in the form of a picture or in words. If you apply RiemannHurwitz, explain first how you compactify the surface.]

    #Riemann Surfaces
    2001

    Let λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ be fixed, non-zero complex numbers, with λ/μ∉R\lambda / \mu \notin \mathbb{R}λ/μ∈/R, and let Λ=Zμ+Zλ\Lambda=\mathbb{Z} \mu+\mathbb{Z} \lambdaΛ=Zμ+Zλ be the lattice they generate in C\mathbb{C}C. The series

    ℘(z)=1z2+∑m,n[1(z−mλ−nμ)2−1(mλ+nμ)2]\wp(z)=\frac{1}{z^{2}}+\sum_{m, n}\left[\frac{1}{(z-m \lambda-n \mu)^{2}}-\frac{1}{(m \lambda+n \mu)^{2}}\right] ℘(z)=z21​+m,n∑​[(z−mλ−nμ)21​−(mλ+nμ)21​]

    with the sum taken over all pairs (m,n)∈Z×Z(m, n) \in \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z}(m,n)∈Z×Z other than (0,0)(0,0)(0,0), is known to converge to an elliptic function, meaning a meromorphic function ℘:C→C∪{∞}\wp: \mathbb{C} \rightarrow \mathbb{C} \cup\{\infty\}℘:C→C∪{∞} satisfying ℘(z)=℘(z+μ)=℘(z+λ)\wp(z)=\wp(z+\mu)=\wp(z+\lambda)℘(z)=℘(z+μ)=℘(z+λ) for all z∈Cz \in \mathbb{C}z∈C. ( ℘\wp℘ is called the Weierstrass function.)

    (a) Find the three zeros of ℘′\wp^{\prime}℘′ modulo Λ\LambdaΛ, explaining why there are no others.

    (b) Show that, for any number a∈Ca \in \mathbb{C}a∈C, other than the three values ℘(λ/2),℘(μ/2)\wp(\lambda / 2), \wp(\mu / 2)℘(λ/2),℘(μ/2) and ℘((λ+μ)/2)\wp((\lambda+\mu) / 2)℘((λ+μ)/2), the equation ℘(z)=a\wp(z)=a℘(z)=a has exactly two solutions, modulo Λ\LambdaΛ; whereas, for each of the specified values, it has a single solution.

    [In (a) and (b), you may use, without proof, any known results about valencies and degrees of holomorphic maps between compact Riemann surfaces, provided you state them correctly.]

    (c) Prove that every even elliptic function ϕ(z)\phi(z)ϕ(z) is a rational function of ℘(z)\wp(z)℘(z); that is, there exists a rational function RRR for which ϕ(z)=R(℘(z))\phi(z)=R(\wp(z))ϕ(z)=R(℘(z)).

  • B1.11

    #Riemann Surfaces
    2002

    (a) Define the notions of (abstract) Riemann surface, holomorphic map, and biholomorphic map between Riemann surfaces.

    (b) Prove the following theorem on the local form of a holomorphic map.

    For a holomorphic map f:R→Sf: R \rightarrow Sf:R→S between Riemann surfaces, which is not constant near a point r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, there exist neighbourhoods UUU of rrr in RRR and VVV of f(r)f(r)f(r) in SSS, together with biholomorphic identifications ϕ:U→Δ,ψ:V→Δ\phi: U \rightarrow \Delta, \psi: V \rightarrow \Deltaϕ:U→Δ,ψ:V→Δ, such that (ψ∘f)(x)=ϕ(x)n(\psi \circ f)(x)=\phi(x)^{n}(ψ∘f)(x)=ϕ(x)n, for all x∈Ux \in Ux∈U.

    (c) Prove further that a non-constant holomorphic map between compact, connected Riemann surfaces is surjective.

    (d) Deduce from (c) the fundamental theorem of algebra.

    A holomorphic map p:S→Tp: S \rightarrow Tp:S→T between Riemann surfaces is called a covering map if every t∈Tt \in Tt∈T has a neighbourhood VVV for which p−1(V)p^{-1}(V)p−1(V) breaks up as a disjoint union of open subsets UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ on which p:Uα→Vp: U_{\alpha} \rightarrow Vp:Uα​→V is biholomorphic.

    (a) Suppose that f:R→Tf: R \rightarrow Tf:R→T is any holomorphic map of connected Riemann surfaces, RRR is simply connected and p:S→Tp: S \rightarrow Tp:S→T is a covering map. By considering the lifts of paths from TTT to SSS, or otherwise, prove that fff lifts to a holomorphic map f~:R→S\widetilde{f}: R \rightarrow Sf​:R→S, i.e. that there exists an f~\widetilde{f}f​ with f=p∘f~f=p \circ \widetilde{f}f=p∘f​.

    (b) Write down a biholomorphic map from the unit disk Δ={z∈C:∣z∣<1}\Delta=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|z|<1\}Δ={z∈C:∣z∣<1} onto a half-plane. Show that the unit disk Δ\DeltaΔ uniformizes the punctured unit disk Δ×=Δ−{0}\Delta^{\times}=\Delta-\{0\}Δ×=Δ−{0} by constructing an explicit covering map p:Δ→Δ×p: \Delta \rightarrow \Delta^{\times}p:Δ→Δ×.

    (c) Using the uniformization theorem, or otherwise, prove that any holomorphic map from C\mathbb{C}C to a compact Riemann surface of genus greater than one is constant.

    Let V0⊂C2V_{0} \subset \mathbb{C}^{2}V0​⊂C2 be the affine curve with equation u2=v2+1u^{2}=v^{2}+1u2=v2+1 and let V⊂P2V \subset \mathbb{P}^{2}V⊂P2 be the corresponding projective curve.
